deliberation: The verse gives instructions for a sign‑act: a brick with Jerusalem engraved on it. The language itself is descriptive, but the brick clearly stands for the city and its fate. I treat that representational use as metonymic/symbolic figurative language.

instances.hebrew_text: קַח־לְךָ לְבֵנָה ... וְחַקּוֹתָ עָלֶיהָ עִיר אֶת־יְרוּשָׁלִָם
instances.english_text: take a brick … and incise on it a city, Jerusalem
ground: the brick depicts and stands for the city and its fate
instances.explanation: The brick functions as a physical stand‑in for Jerusalem: a metonymic/symbolic representation used in a sign‑act to depict the city’s situation.

deliberation: The verse describes siege works erected against the engraved city on the brick. Literally it is about the model, but the enacted siege plainly represents the coming historical siege. I treat the model siege as a figurative representation of the real siege.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתָּ עָלֶיהָ מָצוֹר ... וְשִׂים־עָלֶיהָ כָּרִים סָבִיב
instances.english_text: Set up a siege against it … and bring up battering rams round about it.
vehicle: miniature siege laid against the brick
ground: correspondence between model siege and real siege (encirclement, attack, pressure)
instances.explanation: The siege conducted against the brick is a symbolic enactment of the real siege that will befall Jerusalem, mapping the model military action onto future historical events.

deliberation: Two clear figurative elements: (1) the iron plate as an 'iron wall' between prophet and city, symbolizing an impenetrable barrier; (2) 'set your face against it', a conventional idiom for determined, hostile resolve. Both are part of the sign‑act.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתָּה אוֹתָהּ קִיר בַרְזֶל בֵּינְךָ וּבֵין הָעִיר
instances.english_text: place it as an iron wall between yourself and the city
target: separation and alienation between God (via his prophet) and Jerusalem
posture: emphatic portrayal of judgment and distance
instances.explanation: The iron plate as an 'iron wall' between Ezekiel and the city symbolizes an unbreakable barrier between God and Jerusalem, representing their estrangement and the inevitability of the siege.

target: YHWH’s determined hostility to Jerusalem (embodied in the prophet)
vehicle: face turned resolutely toward an object
ground: firm resolve, hostile attention, unyielding focus
instances.explanation: The idiom 'set your face against' uses the direction of the face metonymically to express firm, hostile resolve toward Jerusalem.

deliberation: The central figurative element is conceptual: Israel’s 'iniquity' is something Ezekiel can 'place' on his side and 'bear'. This treats sin/punishment as a burden resting on and carried by the prophet.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשַׂמְתָּ אֶת־עֲוֹן בֵּית־יִשְׂרָאֵל עָלָיו ... תִּשָּׂא אֶת־עֲוֹנָם
instances.english_text: let it bear the punishment of the House of Israel … you shall bear their punishment
target: guilt and punishment of the northern kingdom
vehicle: a burden placed on and carried by a person’s body
weight to be carried over time
ground: transfer of consequences onto a bearer
posture: prophetic identification with the people’s guilt
instances.explanation: Israel’s iniquity is pictured as a heavy burden that can be laid on Ezekiel’s side and carried, a standard biblical metaphor of guilt/punishment as a load to bear, dramatized through the sign‑act.

deliberation: The verse reiterates the idea of 'bearing' Israel’s iniquity, now tied to a specific number of days. The main figurative element remains the burden metaphor; the counting of days itself is quantitative, not figurative.

instances.english_text: and so you shall bear the punishment for the House of Israel
target: longstanding punishment due to the northern kingdom
vehicle: carrying a load over an extended period
ground: endurance under a weight corresponding to past guilt
posture: underscoring the severity and duration of guilt
instances.explanation: Again, Israel’s punishment is conceptualized as a burden Ezekiel must carry, reinforcing the metaphor of guilt as a load borne by a representative figure.

deliberation: Two figurative aspects appear: (1) 'bear the iniquity of the house of Judah' continues the burden metaphor; (2) 'a day for a year' is a symbolic equivalence where each day in the sign‑act stands for a year of historical guilt/punishment.

instances.english_text: and bear the punishment of the House of Judah
vehicle: a load carried by an individual
ground: tangible experience of otherwise abstract guilt
posture: prophetic solidarity with the judged people
instances.explanation: Judah’s punishment is again treated as a burden that can be carried, extending the metaphor of iniquity as a load borne by Ezekiel.

instances.hebrew_text: אַרְבָּעִים יוֹם יוֹם לַשָּׁנָה יוֹם לַשָּׁנָה נְתַתִּיו לָךְ
instances.english_text: forty days, a day for each year, a day for each year I impose on you
target: time span of sin and judgment
vehicle: forty days of lying on the side
shorter time units in the sign‑act
posture: symbolic encoding of time in the sign‑act
instances.explanation: Each day of Ezekiel’s action symbolically stands for a year of Judah’s guilt, a metaphorical compression of time functioning as prophetic numerical symbolism.

deliberation: Two idiomatic/figurative bodily expressions: (1) 'set your face toward besieged Jerusalem' as a stance of hostile resolve; (2) 'with bared arm' as a metonymy for ready, active power/judgment.

instances.english_text: set your face toward besieged Jerusalem
target: stance of judgment against the city
intent to pronounce and enact doom
vehicle: face deliberately directed toward an object
instances.explanation: The idiom uses Ezekiel’s 'face' as a metonym for his (and God’s) determined, hostile intent toward Jerusalem, dramatized in bodily orientation.

target: ready exercise of prophetic/divine power in judgment
vehicle: bare arm prepared for work or battle
ground: lack of hindrance to exerting power
posture: urgent readiness to act in judgment
instances.explanation: The exposed arm stands metonymically for the prophet’s (and God’s) power and readiness to act, a bodily symbol of imminent, forceful intervention.

deliberation: The cords may be literal in the vision, but their function is symbolic: Ezekiel’s enforced immobility parallels the fixed, inescapable state of the siege. I treat the imposed cords as a figurative sign‑act of unavoidable judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה נָתַתִּי עָלֶיךָ עֲבוֹתִים וְלֹא־תֵהָפֵךְ מִצִּדְּךָ אֶל־צִדֶּךָ עַד־כַּלּוֹתְךָ יְמֵי מְצוּרֶךָ
instances.english_text: Now I put cords upon you, so that you cannot turn from side to side until you complete your days of siege.
target: the inevitability and fixed duration of Jerusalem’s siege
unrelenting conditions of the coming catastrophe
vehicle: a bound man unable to turn because of cords
ground: being held fast until a set term is fulfilled
posture: didactic emphasis on the siege’s fixed course
instances.explanation: The cords restraining Ezekiel function as a metaphorical and symbolic depiction of Jerusalem’s helplessness under an unavoidable, time‑fixed siege.

deliberation: All items (grains/legumes) are literal, but combining them into one vessel for bread is an unnatural, poor‑man’s mixture, functioning in context as a sign of scarcity and degradation under siege. I treat the mixed bread as symbolic/figurative within the sign‑act.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתָּ אוֹתָם בִּכְלִי אֶחָד וְעָשִׂיתָ אוֹתָם לְךָ לְלָחֶם
instances.english_text: Put them into one vessel and bake them into bread for yourself
target: future conditions of scarcity and poor diet in the siege/exile
vehicle: improvised bread from a mixture of grains and legumes
ground: makeshift, impoverished food, lacking purity or abundance
sign of hardship and lack of choice
posture: dramatic evocation of poverty and siege
instances.explanation: The unusual mixed bread functions metonymically and symbolically for the meager, degraded sustenance God’s people will have under siege and in exile.

deliberation: The instruction to eat food 'by weight' at a small daily ration is literal for Ezekiel’s sign‑act but symbolic of famine‑like rationing. I treat this ration‑by‑weight motif as a figurative sign of scarcity.

instances.hebrew_text: מַאֲכָלְךָ אֲשֶׁר תֹּאכְלֶנּוּ בְּמִשְׁקֹל עֶשְׂרִים שֶׁקֶל לַיּוֹם
instances.english_text: The food that you eat shall be by weight, twenty shekels a day
ground: tight control, insufficiency, anxiety about provision
absence of abundance or freedom in eating
instances.explanation: The meticulous weighing of small food portions in the sign‑act symbolizes the rationing and scarcity that will characterize Jerusalem under judgment.

deliberation: Similarly to v.10, measured water rations are literal instructions within the sign‑act but symbolically depict extreme scarcity and anxiety. This is a parallel sign of deprivation.

instances.english_text: And you shall drink water by measure; a sixth of a hin you shall drink
target: future lack of water in siege/exile
vehicle: strictly measured small quantity of water
ground: loss of normal ease in drinking
instances.explanation: The carefully measured, meager water ration symbolizes the severe scarcity and anxiety the people will experience under judgment.

deliberation: Baking the barley cake over human excrement is literal within the sign‑act, but it functions symbolically to depict ritual/ceremonial defilement of food in exile. The shocking fuel choice is the figurative element.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִיא בְּגֶלְלֵי צֵאת הָאָדָם תְּעֻגֶנָה לְעֵינֵיהֶם
instances.english_text: you shall bake it on human excrement before their eyes
target: defiled food practices of Israel in exile
ritual and cultural pollution among the nations
vehicle: use of unclean fuel associated with filth
instances.explanation: The command to bake bread over human dung is a symbolic act metonymically portraying the ritual and cultural defilement that will mark Israel’s life among the nations.

deliberation: Here the Lord explicitly interprets the sign: Israel will eat 'their bread, impure, among the nations.' The primary figurative element is 'bread' as a metonym for their overall sustenance and way of life in exile; 'impure' is literal in ritual terms.

instances.hebrew_text: כָּכָה יֹאכְלוּ בְנֵי־יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶת־לַחְמָם טָמֵא בַּגּוֹיִם
instances.english_text: thus shall the people of Israel eat their bread, impure, among the nations
target: Israel’s entire diet and daily sustenance in exile
their lived existence among the nations
ground: bread stands for overall nourishment and daily life
defiled bread implies a defiled way of living
violation of holiness in ordinary sustenance
posture: lamenting prediction of profaned daily life
warning about loss of ritual distinctiveness
instances.explanation: By speaking of their 'bread' as impure among the nations, the text uses 'bread' metonymically for all their sustenance and daily life, indicating comprehensive ritual and cultural defilement.

deliberation: Ezekiel protests that he has never eaten carcass or torn meat. The terms for carcass, torn animal, and 'foul flesh' are technical/ritual and used literally. I see no clear metaphor, idiom, or other figurative device here; it is straightforward autobiographical protest.

The substitution of cow dung for human excrement modifies but does not cancel the defilement symbolism. Cow dung is still an unusual, humbling fuel for bread, and continues the sign‑act’s symbolic portrayal of degraded conditions.

instances.hebrew_text: נָתַתִּי לְךָ אֶת־צְפִיעֵי הַבָּקָר תַּחַת גֶּלְלֵי הָאָדָם וְעָשִׂיתָ אֶת־לַחְמְךָ עֲלֵיהֶם
instances.english_text: I allow you cow’s dung instead of human excrement; prepare your bread on that.
target: continued but mitigated ritual and social defilement
vehicle: baking bread over cow dung instead of human dung
ground: poverty, lack of normal fuel, social humiliation
departure from ideal purity though less extreme than human waste
posture: somewhat compassionate concession yet still judgmental
maintains symbolic force while easing extremity
instances.explanation: Using cow dung as fuel remains a symbolic act of degraded, uncomfortable existence, metonymically depicting the humbling and defiling conditions Israel will face.

deliberation: A key lexical metaphor appears: 'I am going to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem.' 'Staff' evokes a walking stick that supports, so 'staff of bread' pictures food as the support of life. Breaking it signifies removing that support. The rest (eating by weight, drinking by measure) is literal description of siege rationing, though thematically echoing earlier symbolic acts.

instances.english_text: I am going to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem
target: Jerusalem’s food supply and means of survival
basic economic support of the population
vehicle: a staff that one leans on for support
ground: dependence on bread for life as one depends on a staff for support
removal of support leads to collapse
vulnerability when the prop is broken
posture: emphasis on God’s control over sustenance
warning of impending famine and collapse
instances.explanation: By calling bread the 'staff' and announcing that this staff will be broken, the verse metaphorically portrays God’s removal of the people’s basic support and sustenance.

deliberation: The people will lack bread and water (literal), 'be appalled/stunned' at one another (emotional reaction, largely literal), and 'waste away in their iniquity.' The last expression uses the verb for physical wasting/melting to describe the consuming effect of guilt, a standard metaphor of sin as a wasting disease.

instances.english_text: and they shall waste away in their iniquity
target: the people’s experience under the weight of their sin
effects of guilt and judgment on Israel
inner and outer deterioration due to iniquity
vehicle: a body wasting away or melting
ground: gradual weakening and destruction caused by sin, like a wasting illness
helpless decline under an internal burden
posture: somber, diagnostic portrayal of sin’s consequences
instances.explanation: The phrase pictures guilt as something that causes people to 'waste away' like a body decaying from disease, a metaphor for the consuming, destructive effect of iniquity.
